author: sky.cactus
content: Not complete, but it sounds like you are looking for somewhere to start.

author: sky.cactus
content: `geth` is written in Go, not JavaScript.  It exposes a JSON-RPC server API over HTTP/WS/IPC and many clients that connect to it are written in JS (some subset of which use `web3.js` library).

author: hidaloop
content:
Yep, I understand that üôÇ My confusion was the decision to use go string variables with JavaScript syntax in them. Like on the photo.

But it doesn't matter that much, was simply curious.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't know what this screenshot is from.

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: This is geth's definition of the rpc methods

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The implementations are written in go, but we need the definitions in js to give them to the goja compiler

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: This allows us to call them from the java script console. It has nothing to do with the JSON-RPC API server

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: (We just server the same things over the js console as we do over the JSON-RPC server)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content: The api's are usually defined in `api.go` files (e.g. `internal/ethapi/api.go`)

author: hidaloop
content: Ah sorry for being not specific enough. This is `go-ethereum` project the file that contains this variable is `internal/web3ext/web3ext.go`

author: hidaloop
content: Aha, this is exactly what I needed to hear. Thank you so much!

author: hidaloop
content:
Great, thank you very much once again!
I would just prefer using protocol implementation as a source of truth, rather than external source (be it an "official" one).

author: sky.cactus
content: To be clear, there are 5 different actively maintained clients that implement the JSON-RPC API, and none of them is more "official" than the other.

author: sky.cactus
content: The link I provided above is an attempt at standardization (which will be official once completed).

author: hidaloop
content: Yes, of course, again sorry for being unclear.

author: hidaloop
content: Thank you, guys, for being responsive. I really appreciate your help!
